info.game_comments:
Isaac Segal game 5.
First game of Season 12.

(1, 1).clue: The last monarch crowned in this church was Elizabeth II

(2, 1).clue: A 1960 Emmy for drama writing went to this creator of the "Twilight Zone"

(3, 1).clue: The early Romans used it as an ointment; we use it on toast & baked potatoes

(4, 1).clue: He organized the corps of men who photographed the Civil War; poor eyesight limited his work

(5, 1).clue: When joining copper water pipes, use solder free of this heavy metal once commonly used in plumbing

(6, 1).clue: Russian city where Nadia Comaneci  competed in her second Olympics

(1, 2).clue: St. Helen's Bishopsgate is one of the few churches that survived this 1666 event

(2, 2).clue: In 1990 & 1991 this Fox show was named the outstanding animated prime-time series

(3, 2).clue: The brittle of peanut brittle includes sugar, water, baking soda & this syrup

(4, 2).clue: Elizabeth Gurley Flynn, a founder of the ACLU, was expelled in 1940 for being a member of this party

(5, 2).clue: Of 20, 200 or 2000 gallons, the amount of water used by the average American household each day

(6, 2).clue: Nicknamed "Sir Charles", he was part of the gold-medal-winning 1992 U.S. "Dream Team"

(1, 3).clue: Some of these are Battersea, Regent's & Hyde

(2, 3).clue: When accepting his Emmy for "Saturday Night Live" in 1976, he took one of his trademark pratfalls

(3, 3).clue: Classically, this French dish is an old rooster cooked in wine; you can use a game hen

(4, 3).clue: Over half the value of U.S. exports from 1815-1860 came from this crop

(5, 3).clue: This common home device has a relief valve to prevent an explosion in case of thermostat failure

(6, 3).clue: In this sport's individual event all 64 competitors shoot at targets 70 meters away at the same time

(1, 4).clue: Opened in 1897, this gallery of modern British art was named for a sugar merchant

(2, 4).clue: This sitcom's Laurie Metcalf received Emmys in 1992, '93 & '94 for her role as Jackie

(3, 4).clue: Cultivated in hothouses, the button is a common one of these

(4, 4).clue: The Bay of Pigs invasion plans were first drawn up under this president

(5, 4).clue: In the ion-exchange type of this device, hard water is filtered through a material called zeolite

(6, 4).clue: At the 1984 L.A. games, she won a silver in the heptathlon & her brother Al, a gold in the triple jump

(1, 5).clue: The address of this world-famous auction house is 34-35 New Bond Street

(2, 5).clue: In 1982 this 3-time Oscar winner won an Emmy for her performance in "A Woman Called Golda"

(3, 5).clue: Added to punch or hung in the closet, it's a fruit studded with cloves & then dried

(4, 5).clue: In 1930 Charles Evans Hughes left the World Court to take this position in the U.S.
(4, 5).correct response: Chief Justice of the U.S. Supreme Court

(5, 5).clue: Found beneath a sink, this U- or P-shaped pipe maintains a water seal to keep sewer gas out of your house

(6, 5).clue: The 3 throwing events in the decathlon

(1, 1).clue: Reinhold Messner became the first person in history to climb the 14 highest of these

(2, 1).clue: The nickname "The Wizard of Menlo Park" was invented for him

(3, 1).clue: About 1 in 20 Americans has this illness characterized by breathlessness & wheezing

(4, 1).clue: Sindhi is spoken mainly in the Sind province of Pakistan & this neighboring country

(5, 1).clue: In his poems "Lenore" & "The Raven", young men lament the deaths of their beloveds

(6, 1).clue: The first use of artificial rain to fight a forest fire was in 1947 near Concord in this "Granite State"

(1, 2).clue: He spoke out for the rights of Indians & Eskimos when he became the first reigning pope to visit Canada

(2, 2).clue: Otto von Bismarck was the Iron Chancellor & he was the Iron Duke

(3, 2).clue: During childhood the yellow form of this replaces the more active red type inside some of your bones

(4, 2).clue: The low form of this language is also known as Plattdeutsch

(5, 2).clue: In "American Names", Stephen Vincent Benet said to "Bury" this "at Wounded Knee"

(6, 2).clue: Anne Whitney, a self-taught artist from this state, sculpted the statue of Samuel Adams for the U.S. Capitol

(1, 3).clue: Brian Boitano won the gold in men's figure skating at the 1988 Winter Olympics in this North American city

(2, 3).clue: James Stuart was "The Old" one, Charles Edward Stuart "The Young" one

(3, 3).clue: The tearing of these muscles at the back of the thigh is common in sports like sprinting

(4, 3).clue: Aragonese is a dialect of this language

(5, 3).clue: The reputation of poet Wolfram von Eschenbach rests largely on "Parzival", an epic of this holy object

(6, 3).clue: Hammersmith Farm, the Auchincloss family's Newport, R.I. home, was the site of this couple's 1953 wedding reception

(1, 4).clue: This musical about an artist became the 1st play with a day of the week in its title to win a Pulitzer Prize
(1, 4).correct response: Sunday in the Park with George

(2, 4).clue: In the singular it referred to Mary Pickford, in the plural to Nelson Eddy & Jeanette MacDonald

(3, 4).clue: Astigmatism occurs when the front surface of this part of the eye is not truly spherical

(4, 4).clue: The poetry & novels of Shaaban Robert renewed interest in literature written in this Bantu language

(5, 4).clue: He wrote, "It is an ancient mariner, and he stoppeth one of three"

(6, 4).clue: Rockland, the "Schooner Capital of" this state, celebrates Schooner Days once a year

(1, 5).clue: Elizabeth II officially opened World Expo 88 while touring this country during its bicentennial

(2, 5).clue: Singer Jenny Lind was the Swedish Nightingale & this French chanteuse was the Little Sparrow

(3, 5).clue: This simple sugar is the body's chief source of energy for cell metabolism

(4, 5).clue: This alphabet is considered the prototype of the Cyrillic language

(5, 5).clue: Izaak Walton wrote a moving but inaccurate biography of this "For Whom the Bell Tolls" poet

(6, 5).clue: This state has the lowest population east of the Mississippi River

(0, 0).clue: Other than in Germany, the U.S. has more military personnel stationed in this foreign country than in any other
